properties.Description: Spontaneous combustion at coal sheds consumes nearly 6,000 tons of fuel.
Refinery fire.
Explosion of tank (kerosene).
Explosion of still (crude oil).
Lightning-caused explosion of two tanks (kerosene).
Explosion of agitator at small refinery.
Explosion of leaking sill (kerosene).
Explosion of still (petroleum).
Lightning-caused conflagration destroys refinery, storage facilities, wharves, and several vessels, burning up tens of thousands of barrels of fuel, at a loss of hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Workplace accident inside still (explosion of kerosene lamp).
Explosion of tank (benzene) spreads fire throughout refinery.
Explosion of still (kerosene).
Explosion of tank spreads fire throughout refinery.
Explosion of tank (benzene) spreads fire throughout refinery.
Explosion of still under repair.
Barge carrying kerosene sinks, spilling contents, and covering surface of river from its mouth to Vine Street.
Explosion of magazine.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (kerosene).
Lightning-caused explosion of tank becomes major conflagration.
Fire at kerosene storage warehouse.
Fire destroys alum and acid buildings at chemical works.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (benzene).
Explosion of tank.
Fire at sulphur acid building at chemical works.
Explosion of still spreads fire to other stills.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (distilled oil) —same tank that attracted lightning in 1884— leads to fire that lasts about five hours.
Explosion of naphtha.
properties.Responsible corporate entity: Gibson Point Oil Warehouse (Bosshardt and Wilson)

properties.Description: Explosion of still (steam and oil).
British tanker ship Thordisa catches fire while loading kerosene bound for France.
Explosion of still.
Explosion on tanker ship Hans und Kurt (refined oil) during loading.
Three tanks (oil, benzene) catch on fire, which spreads to buildings.
Explosion of tanker ship Standard (refined oil).
Workplace accident (explosion of air pressure device).
Explosion of leaking oil pipes burns wharves, boats, and threatens gas works; river catches fire.
River catches fire after continued oil spill from leaking pipes.
Explosion of boiler.
Explosion of purifying house.
Explosion of tank.
Explosion of escaped gas destroys receiving department building.
Fire in asphalt plant.
Fire burns paraffin works, wharves, and one vessel.
Lightning-caused explosion of tanks.
Large fire at naphtha soap plant.
Four-alarm fire destroys small refinery.
Oil from ruptured pipeline threatens Mingo Creek; workers divert spill into a diked meadow, then light on fire.
Explosion of pipes and tanks (benzene).
Fire in stable.
Explosion of tank (kerosene) leads to fire in illuminating gas factory.
Fire in still (hot tar).
Explosion of stills (hot tar).
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (benzene) becomes conflagration, causes about $500,000 in property loss, including some 150,000 barrels of oil.
properties.Street coordinates: Just south of Passyunk Ave, opposite UGI office

properties.Description: Lightning-caused explosion of tank (naphtha); fire lasts 3 hours.
Explosion of pipe (boiling water).
Match-lit explosion of railroad tank car (benzene).
Still (crude oil) catches fire.
Fire in asphalt plant.
properties.Street coordinates: Grays Ferry Ave Bridge at east bank

properties.Description: Fire in can and box factory lasts 3 hours.
Fire in lubricating oil plant.
Explosion of 2.5-million-cubic-foot gas holder.
Fire in coal gas plant.
Fire in lubricating oil plant.
Explosion of tank (oil).
Explosion of safety valve causes feed pipe to fall in paraffin plant.
Conflagration leads to general destruction, lasts 12 hours, causes about $400,000 in property loss.
Fire in compounding room of chemical building.
properties.Street coordinates: Passyunk Ave and League Island Rd

properties.Description: Explosion of two tanks (oil) becomes large fire.
Explosion in oil testing room.
Workplace accident (chemical burn).
Explosion of still destroying many tanks; four-alarm fire lasts about 15 hours, causes about $500,000 in property loss.
Lightning-caused explosion of mixing tank becomes large fire.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (coal tar) spreads to city's gas works; four-alarm fire.
Break in pipe (nitric acid) at chemical works leads to 15-alarm fire.
Multi-day fire causes widespread damage.
Tanker ship fire spreads to wharves and neighboring vessels, causes about $1 million in property loss.
Explosion of five tanks threatens city gas works; five-alarm fire.
Explosion of still (steam) leads to explosion of tanks (refined oil); six-alarm fire lasts for days, causes about $1 million in property loss.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (gasoline).
Explosion of still (naphtha).
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (gasoline).
Refinery fire.
Two stills (crude oil) catch on fire.
Explosion of still (coke).
Still (crude oil) catches fire.
Oil-drenched riverbank, site of a dump, catches fire.
properties.Street coordinates: Passyunk Ave Bridge at west bank

properties.Description: Explosion of still (crude oil).
Explosion of tank (gasoline); fire lasts about two hours.
Explosion in engine room of tugboat VanDyke sinks the craft.
Explosion of still (oil) spreads flames to numerous other stills; fire lasts about 4 hours.
Explosion of barge carrying gasoline.
Two separate explosions of tanks (sulphur) on same day.
Four-alarm fire causes general damage to coal tar distillery.
Explosion of tank (oil).
Fire in shanty by pier leads to fire in warehouse storing kerosene; loss of some 70,000 barrels of fuel.
properties.Street coordinates: 100 feet south of Penrose Ave (Platt) Bridge

properties.Description: Three-alarm fire.
Explosion of gas stabilization plant causes about $900,000 in property loss.
Explosion of still.
Explosion of tank (crude oil); two-alarm fire.
Explosion of tank.
Explosion of still.
properties.Street coordinates: Point Breeze Ave near Schuylkill River

properties.Description: Explosion of stills and tanks; the blast, felt in Camden, New Jersey, breaks windows and doors in South Philadelphia; resulting four-alarm fire lasts about two hours.
Explosion of still (coal tar).
Small coal tar fire.
Two-alarm coal tar fire.
Four-alarm fire at soap factory causes explosions and thick black smoke; 30 fire companies work for hours to keep flames away from tanks of naphtha.
Explosion of still.
Explosion of vat in varnish distillery.
Explosion of tanker ship (crude oil) from Venezuela.
Explosion of cracking unit.
Explosion of pumping unit; five-alarm fire.
Explosion of gas generator.
Explosion of tank (crude oil).
Explosion of experimental still.
Explosion of still.
Lightning-caused accident destroys twenty tanks; eight-alarm fire lasts at least seven hours, and causes about $1 million in property loss.
Puncture of pipeline (crude oil) on bed of Schuylkill River near Penrose Ferry Bridge leads of escape of 28,000 barrels.
Explosion of cracking still (crude oil); four-alarm fire lasts 2.5 hours.
Explosion of storm sewer tunnel infused with refinery leakage.
Spill of 700,000 gallons (gasoline) around tank farm and into Schuylkill River.
Lightning-caused explosion of 100,000-gallon tank (butane).
Explosion of distillation tower (benzene and cumene); five-alarm fire lasts 3.5 hours.
Explosion of fuel line in boiler room; four-alarm fire lasts three hours.
Explosion of still after failure of heat exchanger; three-alarm fire.
Explosion of tank (sulphuric acid); four-alarm fire.
Explosion of pipe ignites large still (high-octane gasoline); five-alarm five causes about $1 million in property loss.
Explosion of two gasoline tanks; six-alarm fire last about 14 hours.
Five-alarm fire destroys three phenol tanks and five extractor towers.
Explosion of pipeline and some 70 drums (naphtha); seven-alarm fire.
Explosion of 13-story catalytic cracking unit leads to conflagration and general destruction, about $900,000 in property loss.
Explosion of still (gasoline); two-alarm fire lasts 90 minutes.
Small fire (gasoline additives).
Spill of 3,000 barrels (crude oil) into Delaware River from tanker ship William Larimer Mellon.
Spill of 200,000 gallons (heating oil) into Schuylkill River from tank farm.
Explosion of tanker ship Elias and loss of about 12,000 barrels of Venezuelan crude oil (mostly burned off rather than spilled); 13 people killed.
Two-alarm fire destroys cooling tower.
Explosion of fuel line; six-alarm fire burns for 2.5 hours.
properties.Street coordinates: Near Penrose Ave (Platt) Bridge, east side

properties.Description: Explosion of pipes (crude oil); eleven-alarm fire over ten days causes about $11 million in property loss, including some 200,000 barrels of fuel; eight city firefighters killed.
Spill of 50,000 gallons (crude oil) into Schuylkill River from refinery.
properties.Street coordinates: Between Penrose Ave (Platt) Bridge and Girard Point (I-95) Bridge

properties.Description: Explosion of pump and pipe (tertiary butyl alcohol); nine-alarm fire lasts 34 hours.
Failure of pump in distillery (crude oil) that had been inspected days before; six-alarm fire lasts about nine hours.
Five-alarm fire at 45,000-barrel asphalt storage tank.
Two-alarm fire at ruptured line (crude oil) leading to cracking unit.
Explosion of tanks (heavy gas oil), which shakes and damages thousands of homes; five-alarm fire lasts two hours.
Explosion of oil barge leads to six-alarm fire on both sides of Schuylkill; river catches fire.
properties.Street coordinates: Between Penrose Ave (Platt) Bridge and Girard Point (I-95) Bridge

properties.Description: Spill of 20,000 gallons (heating oil) into Schuylkill River from tank farm.
Seal failure in a pump at oil-processing still leads to two-alarm fire.
Six-alarm fire.
Blown valve leads to leakage of tank (butane); Tasker Homes evacuated.
Explosion of storage tank (naphtha); five-alarm fire
Spill of crude ignites; one-alarm fire.
Broken refining pump seal triggers explosion; three-alarm fire last 1.5 hours.N
properties.Street coordinates: East bank of Schuylkill River upstream of Penrose Ave (Platt) Bridge

properties.Description: Three-alarm fire.
Lightning-caused explosion of tank (gasoline); eight-alarm fire lasts about 31 hours; loss of some 20,000 barrels.
Lightning-caused explosion and collapse of tank (gasoline); five-alarm fire lasts two days, burns some 25,000 barrels of fuel worth about $2 million.
properties.Street coordinates: Near southern end of Essington Ave

properties.Description: Explosion of tank (waste chemicals).
Malfunction causes release of some five tons of silica alumina catalyst.
Explosion of tank (waste chemicals) heard as far away as Bucks County; five-alarm fire lasts about two hours.
Explosion in cracking unit; one-alarm fire last one hour.
Spill of 1,000 gallons (vacuum gas oil) from barge being loaded.
Explosion of broken tube in naphtha processor; four-alarm fire.
Release of 4,000 gallons (jet fuel) from underground line sometime in September (exact date unknown).
Hundreds of used tires stacked by oil storage tanks catch fire.
Release of 1,300 gallons (fuel oil) from transfer line.
Four-alarm propane fire lasts three hours.
Release of 4,400 gallons (naphtha) from 8-inch line.
Three-alarm fire at reformer unit (naphtha and hydrogen) lasts five hours.
properties.Street coordinates: Penrose Ave and Fort Mifflin Rd

properties.Description: Faulty valve in cracking unit releases three yellow clouds of silica alumina coated with oil.
Release of 21,000 gallons (gasoline) from Tank 38.
Small fire (butane and propane).
Heavy snow and ice tips the roofs of two storage tanks (one naphtha, one crude), releasing noxious odors into surrounding neighborhoods for days.
Release of 5,040 gallons (diesel fuel) from Tank 253.
Four-alarm fire in sulfur removal unit leads to large release of silica alumina catalyst.
Release of 8,400 gallons (light naphtha) from Tank 181.
Leak of 192,000 gallons (crude oil) into John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge from ruptured pipeline.
Malfunction causes release of substantial amount of silica alumina catalyst.
Explosion of pipe (gasoline).
Ignition of flammable vapor.
Release of 15,000 gallons (fuel oil) from product line near Tank 676.
Explosion of high-pressure 20-inch pipe (natural gas) causes entire plant to suspend service.
Two-alarm fire in hydrogen unit.
One-alarm fire in cooling tower; black smoke visible for miles.
Release of 239,000 gallons (crude oil) from Tank 885.
Small fire.
Small fire.
One-alarm fire.
Ignition of flammable vapor in alkylation unit leads to fire and explosions, and approximately $750 million in property loss.
Unused fuel storage tank being dismantled by welders catches fire.
Collision of train carrying oil with trolley carrying refinery workers.
